Now, this is a message for @Puzzlemucker. I've been going through the archives and this morning did a puzzle from November 9, 2023 that had ROSANNE Cash as an answer.  You posted a link to her song /video "She Remembers Everything," which I'd never heard before.  I listened to it several times in a row and cried my eyeballs out. So beautiful and poignant. Pretty bad puzzle imo. Bunch of clues that related to old people (no offense) and very difficult to solve the long clues with the cryptic down clues. No "gotcha" moments for me when solving, everything seemed so obscure. A miss for sure.

I'm delighted to see you back, Mrs. Steinberg, and with a first solo themeless to boot! It was a fun solve, with bits and pieces that were breezy and others that were oh-so-chewy that I had to resort to a few lookups to break them open (not that i dont like a challenge, but on Fridays and Saturdays I prefer to keep it stress-free and so i set a time limit to feeling enSNARLed.) SAY THE MAGIC WORD made me smile. Just yesterday I suddenly remembered how, sitting in the backseat of my parents' car, I would ask my mother to please turn on the MAGIC button (yes, back then we didn't press buttons on the radio; we turned them.) Knowing how much I loved music, she always knew what I meant. I loved VAN for [Many a short-term rental.] I wasn't USING THE OLD BEAN until it occurred to me that maybe, just maybe, this wasn't about a home. Parallel thinking to the rescue. (And then, after the aha VAN, my mind landed on another VAN: https://youtu.be/pbZf8GY1-Ag?si=dqFqzx1rmDi0NxIM) Thank you, Mrs. Steinberg for a fabulously satisfying romp. You've truly succeeded in constructing a lovely Friday puzzle!

Really thought I'd lose my streak today, but I've got my first ever 19 day streak! Some of those spanners were *nasty*. A couple Naticks (I actually recently went past Natick with when I was in Boston for Figure Skating Worlds), but the last to fall was LETHRO/LINKS. Thought High Jinks might have worked, but got it in the end

False alarm. Went from the agony of (possible) defeat to the thrill of another filled grid. Now for a sunrise coffee on the lanai (wishful bean-thinking). Deb Aimen gave him a good write up in his debut on 8/1/14* Was it a coincidence that this "Grass Mud Horse" artist AND an alpaca reference were HERD in the same grid? Naughty! Congratulations to Mr. Shortz and his team for providing another reason to celebrate the crossword community. *https://archive.nytimes.com/wordplay.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/07/31/tough-to-figure-out/
‘One of 32 in the NFL’ is wrong. The Green Bay Packers don’t have an owner. They’re publicly owned.
I smiled at the crossing of CROSS and WORD, both part of 15s, in the lower left of the grid. Good luck to everyone competing this weekend!

Nice. Very nice. Enjoyed the cluing, really solid use of the 15-letter entries. Looking back on it, I’d have predicted that the lower left would be lethal for me, because I had absolutely no idea who Ai Weiwei was… but I managed to get it purely from the crossing words, and was intrigued enough to look him up after finishing the puzzle, and that made the night even better. Quite a life story, and some very interesting art.

When you back into an answer like I CALL ‘EM AS I SEE ‘EM — that is, when you get the last part of it first — those triple E’s just look wrong. 

I lost half a minute because I forgot it’s HIGH JINKS and not HIGH JINx. 

Other than that, it was a pretty smooth solving experience. I hadn’t heard KEYBOARD WARRIOR or CROSS AT THE GREEN, but it wasn’t too hard to figure out either one. 

Thanks, Ms Steinberg!

I just love when I'm staring at mostly empty spaces, and suddenly a grid spanning answer appears in my head from just a few of the letters.  

That happened three or four times with this one, and every time was like little fireworks going off in my head.

Not literally, of course, because that would be fatal, probably.

This turned out to be too hard for me. I completed the bottom half of the puzzle no problem, but the top half defeated me, even though I knew some stuff that would have confused me before I learned about it from previous NYT puzzles, like RADON. Given my interest in history I also had some gimmes that may have been hard for others: SIAM, IRENE and LAR.

My problems were too many to describe here, but, for example, I had MaSs for MUSH, which fit with the clue, and even though I had _____THE OLD BEAN, I had no idea what the first word would be: I had few letters in it, including an initial "a" rather than U...

The long expression across the middle of the puzzle was a mystery - I couldn't parse it even when I filled the grid in the end relying on autocheck. I needed another thread in today's comments to understand what was going on there. I would never have got that, myself.

Being Polish, I found OWNER a very weird word relating to NFL. I don't think of sport teams in terms of them having owners. Over here traditionally sports clubs were associations, and many still are, even if they've acquired sponsors over the years. They don't have owners.

I was also confused by having sItU rather than LIEU as "place" (after the DIEs/DIEM controversy recently I thought sItU was a good enough solve for its clue) - it meshed with two other answers there, but completely ruined another two.

So yeah, no gold star for me today, but since I don't care about streaks, that's fine.

A really tough puzzle that I didn't seem to be getting anywhere near solving, but with a few fragmented words for the idiomatic phrases, the ice started breaking and I was in. There were some solid fills that I knew, some flyers that worked, and I was distracted by listening to the Warriors/Lakers game while I was working it (Warriors won!), so I wasn't obsessing about being stuck so many times.  

A favorite moment was when I got at the last three letters of 50A and thought, wait a minute, could that AI WEIWEI?? Went back, changed some earlier letters I had from (wrong) crosses and Yes! What a delight to see him there. So cool.

Thank you, Karen, for a puzzle that was both whimsical and solemn—a welcome pleasure after an awful day.

I came here expecting to read every comment saying this was too easy. Pleasantly surprised to see that is not the case. (Didn’t expect the crossword nerds would be so up in arms about the singularity of NFL ownership). 

In any case. I must have really really been on the same wavelength. Because I had all six long entries figured out almost immediately. (Versus sussing out the long entry from the crosses). Though. Using.Your.noggin. Was my initial guess for 11down.

I just want to put my two cents in. Pigs are far from boorish. This is very unfair. They are fascinating and highly intelligent. Studies have shown they can easily distinguish between an actual object and its reflection. And they are curious. There are not 32 owners in the NFL.  The Green Bay Packers are publicly owned and have issued stock over the years.  As a shareholder, I am an owner, along with thousands of others. It pays no dividends, but I do get voting rights.  This answer is unequivocally wrong.  It would be the same as saying there is only one owner of Apple or Walmart.

Got it--finally! With no outside help. One of the clues is the word STAND. It got me thinking (something I try to avoid). 

A STAND could be:

1. a position
2. the opposite of sit
3. to endure (or abide)
4. a small table

It's when a clue has a multiplicity of possible answers (but really only one) that makes for a good crossword puzzle.

On CROSS AT THE GREEN, I’m reminded of a crosswalk near my office for around 30 years at the university where I taught. At one point, they installed a voice alert for blind people, and for the longest time I thought whoever installed it was trying to be sort of hip, as I heard it as “Hit the road. Walk sign is on.” One day as I stood there, I glanced at the street sign that I’d walked past or stood beside thousands of times. “Edgar Rd.” Just then the signal changed and the voice alert sounded and I realized it was quite mundane: “Edgar Road. Walk sign is on.” I preferred my mishearing.

Thanks for the memories.

A jaywalking story:

For business reasons, my husband moved to Milwaukee almost a year before I did, as I had to stay back to sell the house. He was there without a car, and it was a snowy winter. Living 5 blocks from the office, walking was no big deal until one really blizzard-y day. 

Walking home from the office, with his hood up over his head, also wearing earmuffs, heavy winds beating at him, no real traffic to speak of, he "crossed the street in the middle of the block" and soon heard a siren. As he was a pedestrian, it never occurred to him that the siren was for him, so he continued walking. The police car soon pulled up next to him, and caught his attention. The window rolled down. Yes, with the snow blowing into it. Cop gave him a lecture, as the snow poured down, no other cars passed by, and wind was buffeting my husband so hard he could barely stand still. 

Since Milwaukee was such a friendly city, my husband hoped the cop would take pity on him and drive him the next four blocks to his apartment. Hah! As if...

The cop rolled up his window, after giving him a stiff admonishment for jaywalking, pulled away into the deserted street, and left hubby there, after adding 5 or 10 minutes to his cold and windy walk. Welcome to Wisconsin.

Regarding the number of NFL team owners, strictly speaking, shareholders own the company, not its assets. If you prepare your personal financial statements, on the balance sheet you would list your company shares as an asset, not the team or the company's cash, buildings or other holdings. I'm not an expert on team ownership but in my experience, most families set up a limited liability corporation (or other legal structure) to hold its businesses. My hunch is that most NFL team owners have established some type of legal entity to shield their personal assets from liability due to bankruptcy or personal injury.

Granted, if you ask who owned the Bucs, most people will say the Glazer family.

I subscribe to the Friday Easy Mode newsletter because it often has interesting about crosswords generally. From today’s newsletter:
—————

“I’m wondering what the most common recurring 3 and 4 letter fill letters are over the years…Ana? Eve? Err? NNE? Etta? Otto? Naan?” — Michael Parnes
From Christina:
The most commonly used entry in the New York Times Crossword is ERA. It has been used 739 times in the Will Shortz era and a total of 1,604 times. The top 10 most commonly used entries in the crossword are, in order:
ERA (739)
AREA (601)
ERE (583)
ONE (582)
ELI (565)
ORE (551)
ATE (551)
ALE (537)
ETA (533)
ARE (504)
It’s not hard to spot a pattern here. Nine of the 10 entries are three-letter words with the pattern vowel-consonant-vowel; the 10th is a four-letter word with vowel-consonant-vowel-vowel. Of the 31 letters seen here, there are only seven unique letters, and the most common ones are E, A and R. Alternating consonant-vowel patterns tend to be easiest for constructors to work with in crosswords.

(To be continued)

Many years ago, I saw Richard Leakey speak at Constitution Hall. He opened with this joke:

Mike and Pat travel to New York City for the first time, and are amazed at the number of cars in the streets. Officer Clancy walks up as they're trying desperately to cross Fifth Avenue, and explains, "You see that red light up there? When that turns green, it's safe to cross." Sure enough, the light turns green, and they make it across. They turn back and watch as the light turns amber, and then red again. Mike turns to Pat and says, "Blimey, they don't give the Protestants much of a chance."

In the UK we had a road safety campaign aimed at children during the 1970s. "Always use the green cross code, because I won't be there when you cross the road!" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xR7_Bz9fIPA&ab The Green Cross Code Man was played by bodybuilder Dave Prouse, who went on to fame playing the body, if not the voice, of Darth Vader. (The poor fella is likewise dubbed in my linked advertisement---his Somerset accent was deemed undesirable in a role model for children.)

How can I think about the Lares (and their companions, the Penates) without a brief trip to Leandra, one of Italo Calvino's Invisible Cities? (Although this is a very, very short story, it might take a couple of replies to fit it all in.)

Gods of two species protect the city of Leandra. Both are too tiny to be seen and too numerous to be counted. One species stands at the doors of the houses, inside, next to the coatrack and the umbrella stand; in moves, they follow the families and install themselves in the new home at the consignment of the keys. The others stay in the kitchen, hiding by preference under pots or in the chimney flue or broom closet: they belong to the house, and when the family that has lived there goes away, they remain with the new tenants; perhaps they were already there before the house existed, among the weeds of the vacant lot, concealed in a rusty can; if the house is torn down and a huge block of fifty families is built in its place, they will be found, multiplied, in the kitchens of that many apartments. To distinguish the two species we will call the first one Penates and the other Lares.

This discussion made me wonder what these NFL "teams" actually are. Lo and behold, here is a list of the NFL team entities: https://www.nfl.com/legal/privacy/nfl-entities-list/ Besides Green Bay Packers, Inc, we find New York Football Giants, Inc, Football Northwest LLC, Houston NFL Holdings LP, "Miami Dolphins, Ltd., a Florida limited partnership," and so on. These are the entities that own the teams, with whom the players sign contracts, which own the equipment, etc. Here in Philadelphia, for example, we speak of Jeff Lurie as the owner of the Eagles. While he is the "controlling owner" (holding at least 30% interest) and the face of ownership, the actual owner of the Eagles is Philadelphia Eagles LLC. I think all this makes the clue technically correct. Though I doubt it's what the constructor and editors were thinking!

I’ve got a somewhat embarrassing jaywalking story. 

First week of high school crossing mid-block with a few new friends and I spot a police car approaching as we’re flagrantly breaking the law. Thinking it would be pretty funny, I yell, “Cops!” and lead the sprint off the main thoroughfare and down a residential street to “hide” behind a car. 

The cop thought this looked pretty suspicious and turned to follow us. He demanded to know what we had done and I answered, sheepishly, “Jaywalking”. 

The cop was reluctant to believe it could be something so innocent but eventually let us go with nothing more than an eye roll.

@HeathieJ

Within a given house, Lares do not necessarily stay with Lares, and Penates with Penates: they visit one another, they stroll together on the stucco cornices, on the radiator pipes; they comment on family events; not infrequently they quarrel; but they can also get along peacefully for years— seeing them all in a row, you are unable to tell them apart. The Lares have seen Penates of the most varied origins and customs pass through their walls; the Penates have to make a place for themselves, rubbing elbows with Lares of illustrious, but decaying palaces, full of hauteur, or with Lares from tin shacks, susceptible and distrustful.

The true essence of Leandra is the subject of endless debate. The Penates believe they are the city's soul, even if they arrived last year; and they believe they take Leandra with them when they emigrate. The Lares consider the Penates temporary guests, importunate, intrusive; the real Leandra is theirs, which gives form to all it contains, the Leandra that was there before all these upstarts arrived and that will remain when all have gone away.

The two species have this in common: whatever happens in the family and in the city, they always criticize. The Penates bring out the old people, the great-grandparents, the great-aunts, the family of the past; the Lares talk about the environment before it was ruined. But this does not mean they live only on memories: they daydream of the careers the children will follow when they grow up (the Penates), or what this house in this neighborhood might become (the Lares) if it were in good hands. If you listen carefully, especially at night, you can hear them in the houses of Leandra, murmuring steadily, interrupting one another, huffing, bantering, amid ironic, stifled laughter.
